awd_titl_txt: PFI:BIC - Flexible,equitable, efficient, and effective distribution (FEEED)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a smart service system to assist hunger relief organizations, like food banks, in the Flexible, Equitable, Efficient, and Effective Distribution (FEEED) of food to those in need. One in eight people in America struggle with hunger. Food banks try to connect excess food to these families in need but face many challenges. The true need is uncertain; donated food has a limited shelf life; warehouse networks and receiving agencies have capacity constraints; and the donated food supply is unpredictable in timing, quantity, and quality. These challenges are becoming increasingly complex as food banks must distribute food equitably to those in need, efficiently maximize donated supply, minimize waste and distribute food in a cost effective manner. The existing tools used by food banks provide information to facilitate all levels of decision making but are limited in their ability to (i) provide a comprehensive picture; (ii) recommend improvements; and (iii) learn from and respond to the highly dynamic and uncertain environment. FEEED will synthesize data from various sources to automatically predict, visualize, learn from decision maker?s actions, and identify strategies to advance operational effectiveness of food collection, distribution, and resource management and fundamentally transform the way food banks operate.

FEEED advances the management of complex dynamic distribution systems that require intelligence to effectively utilize data to improve decision making. This research project will involve the exploration and development of: (1) a novel, stochastic modeling framework to adapt to the dynamically changing objectives of the human decision maker, thus enabling the system to learn over time and more effectively recommend solutions tailored to the decision maker's preferences; (2) an intelligent operational guidance engine and knowledge base that help food bank staff operationalize complex modeling into their daily processes; (3) a framework for synthesizing and managing big data in the humanitarian relief sector; and (4) human/machine communication modalities that facilitate user understanding and visualization of smart system analysis, predictions and recommendations. This research addresses the critical intersection of humanitarian relief, engineering, computer science and industry by linking donations management and food distribution to supply chain management and forges a relationship necessary to address this significant global challenge. The proposed research integrates discovery in industrial engineering and computer science with industry best practice knowledge for the development of technology that can be applied for flexible, equitable, efficient, and effective humanitarian relief operations worldwide.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Department of Industrial & systems engineering- NCAT

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in the development of a smart food distribution system that aids decision makers in the flexible, equitable, efficient, and effective distribution (FEEED) of donated food. The FEEED system is designed for non-profit hunger relief organizations that must make storage and allocation decisions in an environment with high uncertainty on the supply and demand side under constrained resource (storage, budget, and workforce) capacity.  Using advanced machine learning and optimization techniques, FEEED can  describe, predict and prescribe the best way to organize large data to improve forecast accuracy; identify the preference of a food bank among the criteria - equity, effectiveness, and efficiency - by analyzing the distribution decision taken by the food bank; suggest optimal strategies to allocate food considering uncertainty in supply, network structure, food demand and objectives to minimize waste and transportation cost while also ensuring equity;  suggest donor classification strategies that aid in more accurate forecasts of donated supply; and provide interactive visualizations of predictive and prescriptive strategies for sourcing and distribution. 


Our project has exposed the complex nature of managing hunger relief supply chains and the integrative nature of systems engineering, mathematics, social science and computational science in the application of data analytics techniques to address a societal need. Furthermore, through the development of the FEEED system, we have provided opportunities that enhance the knowledge base of the existing and emerging workforce. Specifically, through product demonstrations and feedback sessions, we have enhanced the knowledge base of the existing workforce of food bank practitioners by exposing them to the power of optimization, analytics and visualization for (i) quickly assessing their environment and (ii) interpreting solutions from complicated modeling tools which are provided in a user-friendly format.  With respect to the emerging  workforce, research assistantships and internship opportunities with food bank stakeholders and our industry partner have exposed students to the methodologies of user-center design and provided key training in the tools and technologies necessary for translating research to a marketable product. 


 


Last Modified: 12/18/2021
Modified by: Lauren Davis
